Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Intermittent 500: https://api-v2v3search-0.nuget.org/query?" (#9014) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

I'm unable to use NuGet.org

### Describe the bug

Using a browser, or other http client, navigate to **https://api-v2v3search-0.nuget.org/query?q=PackageId:AWSSDK.AWSSupport&prerelease=true**

Reload the page several times.

On at least one reload, observe error message:

```
HTTP Error 500.30 - ANCM In-Process Start Failure
```

### Repro Steps

Steps to reproduce this behavior

1. Navigate to https://api-v2v3search-0.nuget.org/query?q=PackageId:AWSSDK.AWSSupport&prerelease=true
2. Refresh page several times
3. Observe page intermittently returns 500 error.

### Expected Behavior

Navigating to https://api-v2v3search-0.nuget.org/query?q=PackageId:AWSSDK.AWSSupport&prerelease=true should never return a 500 error.

### Screenshots

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1190907/155009635-3ca8bd6c-4803-47b2-a12c-b0d625c1e537.png)

### Additional Context and logs

We have automated monitoring of our packages in NuGet that verify available version history once every 30 minutes.

We first observed a degraded experience on Feb 21st 2022 at approximately 16:10 UTC

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: SearchQueryService doesnt find System.CommandLine" (#9007) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:

Other/NA

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

I'm unable to use this version

### Repro Steps & Context

```
https://azuresearch-usnc.nuget.org/query?q=system.commandline
```

neither

```
nuget search System.CommandLine
```

if you do

```
nuget search System.CommandLine -PreRelease
```
that works,

but

```
https://azuresearch-usnc.nuget.org/query?q=system.commandline&prerelease=true
```

still doesn't show anything

-- compare to --

nuget.org and search for System.CommandLine which actually shows the package

why can't these be found

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Wrong additional computed target frameworks if native dependencies" (#9013) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Describe the bug

Recently a new feature on nuget.org shows the TFMs on each package's page.

When implicit or explicit native dependencies are involved, the binding project page may show it supports a platform that the native package does not support, which can be effectively misleading to users.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3928834/154900580-3f340762-eef2-4959-b38d-e7d605960d3c.png)

Example above. In theory the binding project could run on watchOS or Tizen, but the underlying native dependency does not.

### Repro Steps

1. On https://www.nuget.org/packages/LibVLCSharp/
2. Click "Frameworks"
3. Witness targets like watchOS or Tizen, which are unsupported by LibVLC (while the binding could in theory run on those platforms, it would be useless, so this is misleading).

### Expected Behavior

Maybe a way to indicate that the computed TFMs are an indication and not guaranteed in case of underlying native dependencies.

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed pull request "Fix the font of the framework badges" (#9009) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
The recently introduced frameworks tab contrasts with the rest of the web page on systems that don't have the Segoe UI font installed. For example, on macOS, all the framework badges are rendered with a serif font (Times) whereas the rest of the page is rendered with Helvetica Neue. You can even see it in the screenshots on the blog post announcing the new [Compatible Packages][1] feature!

This commit fixes the `font-family` of all .framework* classes to use the same font family as everywhere else in the css file, i.e. `'Segoe UI', "Helvetica Neue", Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;`

[1]: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/introducing-compatible-frameworks-on-nuget-org/

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[TFM Display] Fix font issue for safari." (#9011) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
* Removed family-font on .framework class, so that css uses the default font.

Addresses: https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/4260.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: IPackageMetadataSearch does not return the "title" of a NuGet package's NuSpec file" (#9010) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened pull request "Fix the font of the framework badges" (#9009) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
The recently introduced frameworks tab contrasts with the rest of the web page on systems that don't have the Segoe UI font installed. For example, on macOS, all the framework badges are rendered with a serif font (Times) whereas the rest of the page is rendered with Helvetica Neue. You can even see it in the screenshots on the blog post announcing the new [Compatible Packages][1] feature!

This commit fixes the `font-family` of all .framework* classes to use the same font family as everywhere else in the css file, i.e. `'Segoe UI', "Helvetica Neue", Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;`

[1]: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/introducing-compatible-frameworks-on-nuget-org/

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[DCR]: Enabled plugins for other protocols" (#11613) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Affected

NuGet SDK

### Current Behavior

Currently plugin discovery is only enabled for HTTP sources.

### Desired Behavior

Plugin should be able to support other protocols, or source types.

### Additional Context

Plugin discovery is only enabled for HTTP sources

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/2ffefa687ba980fd0a70e13615875c69bde9393c/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Protocol/Plugins/PluginManager.cs#L122

This should be relaxed to enable other protocols, and it should be up to the plugin to decide whether it can support the protocol.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: Cannot find convention based plugins" (#11612) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet SDK

### Product Version

6.2.0, or previous

### Worked before?

not tested

### Impact

I'm unable to use this version

### Repro Steps & Context

Convention based plugin discovery is not possible

1. Copy plugin to convention based path (i.e. `$(UserProfile)\.nuget\plugins\netcore\myplugin`)
2. Do not set `NUGET_PLUGIN_PATHS`

Plugin is not found

This appears to be because plugin discovery is only enabled when the source is `http`, and `_rawPluginPaths` is not null or empty

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/2ffefa687ba980fd0a70e13615875c69bde9393c/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Protocol/Plugins/PluginManager.cs#L122

If `_rawPluginPaths` is not set, then plugin discovery is disabled, but when it is set, then convention based discovery is disabled.

This seems to be the case for all versions.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: NuGet Verify failing in windows Docker containers - Unable to disable Verify" (#11611) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet.exe

### Product Version

All nuget.exe versions (5.7 and latest), also present in dotnet restore.

### Worked before?

No verification failures

### Impact

I'm unable to use this version

### Repro Steps & Context

When we build in our azure devops pipelines using docker containers, in the last two months we have encountered intermittent verify failures that we are unable to track down. I've tried moving to the latest nuget.exe, dotnet restore, and nothing has worked, most importantly and relevantly nuget verify disabling. From everything i can find on the history of verify, it was supposed to be opt in - so i should be able to at least temporarily disable verification altogether and not encounter issues. However, all documentation to disable it fails - I still get intermittent trusted root certification errors.

Note: I am not able to change my package versions, .net FW version, or visual studio version due to customer requirements.

I am expecting there is an ability to skip nuget verification on packages that are failing verification improperly. I honestly don't know what the reasoning is - every case I've found was solved with more up to date docker base images, but that has not worked for us.

The error:

##[error]NU3018: Package 'Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.VersionCheckAnalyzer 2.9.4' from source 'C:\__w\81\s\Packages': The author primary signature found a chain building issue: UntrustedRoot: A certificate chain processed, but terminated in a root certificate which is not trusted by the trust provider.

And yes, all the packages are microsoft packages, and yes, it isn't just that one package, and yes, sometimes my builds pass. 



### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: Error: NU1403 Package content hash validation failed for NETStandard.Library.2.0.3. The package is different than the last restore." (#11610) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

MSBuild.exe

### Product Version

MSBuild 17.1.0+ae57d105c, Visual Studio 17.1.0

### Worked before?

MSBuild 17.0.6, Visual Studio 17.0.6

### Impact

I'm unable to use this version

### Repro Steps & Context

To clarify, the impact of this issue is that I can not build our UWP app on any version of any tool without removing the lock file, which is prohibitively risky since it may be catching and preventing a live attack on the Microsoft ecosystem.

Repro steps:

1. Use Visual Studio 17.1.0 to create a default UWP project with a lock file expecting the following hash for `NETStandard.Library.2.0.3`: `"st47PosZSHrjECdjeIzZQbzivYBJFv6P2nv4cj2ypdI204DO+vZ7l5raGMiX4eXMJ53RfOIg+/s4DHVZ54Nu2A=="`. This can be achieved by introducing a direct dependency on [Microsoft.NETCore.UniversalWindowsPlatform.6.2.13](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.NETCore.UniversalWindowsPlatform/6.2.13) and adding the following to your `.csproj`:

```xml
<PropertyGroup>
  <RestoreProjectStyle>PackageReference</RestoreProjectStyle>
  <RestorePackagesWithLockFile>true</RestorePackagesWithLockFile>
</PropertyGroup>
```

You will probably then need to modify the hash in the lock file (`packages.lock.json`) to the value provided above.

2. Build the UWP project in Visual Studio 17.1.0.

Expected result:

The project builds without errors.

Actual result:

The project builds successfully, but reports error NU1403 because of a lock file hash mismatch in `NETStandard.Library.2.0.3`. The error was first observed on February 22nd, 2022 at 18:33 UTC. The same project built successfully without reporting any errors prior to this, and the error has never been encountered before. Nothing was changed between the last successful build and this one, and clearing the NuGet cache had no effect. The error can be reproduced locally on MSBuild 17.1.0 and in CI on MSBuild 17.0.6, so it seems very unlikely that the issue is related to the release of MSBuild 17.1.0.

### Verbose Logs

```shell
Here is the relevant portion of the diagnostic output of MSBuild 17.1.0+ae57d105c:


...
All packages and projects are compatible with UAP,Version=v10.0.17763 (win10-x86-aot). (TaskId:30)
Package content hash validation failed for NETStandard.Library.2.0.3. Expected: st47PosZSHrjECdjeIzZQbzivYBJFv6P2nv4cj2ypdI204DO+vZ7l5raGMiX4eXMJ53RfOIg+/s4DHVZ54Nu2A== Actual: 548M6mnBSJWxsIlkQHfbzoYxpiYFXZZSL00p4GHYv8PkiqFBnnT68mW5mGEsA/ch9fDO9GkPgkFQpWiXZN7mAQ== (TaskId:30)
14:12:32.118
...
```

The full diagnostic log unfortunately reveals too much proprietary information to disclose publicly (including the name of every single file in the repository, for example), but I suspect the remainder of the contents will not be of much assistance in this particular case.
```
